Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for the 2019 HPCA/CGO/PPoPP Symposia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support approximately 24 students to attend three co-located conferences: 2019 High-Performance Computer Architecture (HPCA), Code Generation and Optimization (CGO), and ACM SIGPLAN Symposium on Principles and Practice of Parallel Programming (PPoPP). These symposia have leading researchers attending from academia, both students and faculty, and from industry. The symposia were held annually separately for many years, and jointly since 2013. Students who will attend the conferences will be exposed to intellectually stimulating research by attending the many talks, panels, keynotes, and poster presentations at the conferences.

Students receiving travel grants through this award will learn the importance of good communication skills as well as learn about what it takes to conduct high quality research, through interactions with speakers, faculty, and peer student groups. The award also seeks to enhance the diversity of the attendees, thus maintain a balance between underrepresented and other groups among the participants supported from the grant.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (CGO 2019), the International Symposium on High-Performance Computer Architecture (HPCA 2019), and the International Symposium on Principles and Practice of Parallel Programming (PPoPP 2019) were jointly and successfully held in Washington D.C., USA from February 16 - 20, 2019. The symposia had jointly applied for and were awarded NSF Grant CCF-1854581 in the amount of $30,000.00 to partially reimburse the travel expenses of students who participated in the symposia. The Principal Investigator for the grant was Sudeep Pasricha, who was the Student Travel Chair for HPCA 2019. He is a Professor in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering and the Department of Computer Science at Colorado State University in Fort Collins, CO. The CSU Engineering Business Office administered the grant funds without overhead, and all the funds were divided among applicants from the three symposia.

 

The three symposia are leaders in their respective fields, and each traditionally has had high rates of student attendance and participation. Co-location in Washington D.C., USA offered unique opportunities for U.S. students to interact with international students, senior researchers, and developers in these fields. Such interactions improved mutual understanding and created opportunities for future collaborations. All the students supported by this grant attended U.S. universities when they applied, and they flew on U.S.-flagged carriers. Each student submitted a cover letter stating his or her reason for attending one of the symposia, a resume, a description of his or her research interests, and a letter from the student's advisor that confirmed the student's eligibility and recommended that the student attend the symposium.

 

The selection process by the symposia organizing committees considered each applicant’s level of participation (paper author and presenter, poster session, or organizer), how closely the student's research interests matched areas covered by the respective symposium, and the advisor's endorsement of the student's potential for research. The symposia made various coordinated efforts to encourage women and underrepresented minorities (URMs) to attend and apply for travel support by this grant. The calls for papers and participation that were on the symposia websites and sent to mailing lists explicitly stated that there are opportunities for student travel grants, with special encouragement provided to women and URMs to apply.

 

The selection committee received applications from multiple female and URM applicants, and the committee provided travel support to all of them. The grant supported 35 students in total across the three symposia and 3 additional students who attended the Young Architect’s Workshop that was co-located with the symposia. Out of these recipients, 10 of the students were female and 1 was a URM student. Given the relatively low numbers of women and URMs pursuing advanced degrees in the computing fields, this support was crucial to provide all of the female and URM applicants with an opportunity to interact with the leaders in industry and academia at the symposia, as well as be exposed to new ideas and opportunities for research.

 

At the symposia, all students attended workshops and talks given by experts from both industry and academia. Many of the presenters were students, and students also participated in poster sessions. There were numerous informal meetings during breaks. The final reports submitted by student travel awardees indicated an overwhelmingly positive and enriching experience, and a gratitude towards NSF for providing the students with an opportunity to attend the symposia, which would not have been possible without NSF’s support.
